Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Low Temperature Cofired Multilayer Ceramic Power Transformers Incorporating Base Metallization Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to a wide range of electronics in the areas of communications, Internet, portable electronics, and power electronics. Although magnetic based transformers have been the industry standard for over a century they have many negatives including miniaturization difficulties, electromagnetic interference issues, and issues with larger voltage step-up applications. The main goal of the research is to develop a ceramic replacement for magnetic transformers that is both conducive to miniaturization, provides higher power densities, provides a large increase in safe operating temperatures, and that is cost competitive with standard magnetic devices. This technology will provide important advantages for many applications; the ability to produce at low cost also opens up large new markets that are not easily reached using conventional magnetics.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase 2 project aims to develop new low temperature sintering processes and transformer structures that enable the use of base metal electrodes to replace very expensive platinum. This drastically reduces costs of ceramic transformers and substantially improves performance due to the fact that a poor electrical/thermal conductor, Platinum, is now replaced with base metal (Copper) that is a high performance electrical/thermal conductor. This translates into both higher power throughput in devices that are lighter weight and lower profile and also a new ability to now match the high temperature range of wide bandgap power devices. The success of this program immediately leads to a revolutionary next step of being able to insert power management/conversion electronics directly within integrated circuits such as in application specific integrated circuits (ASIC) and field programmable gate arrays (FPGA).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF Phase II STTR project, we successfully developed high power density hard-type piezoelectric ceramics and associated new thick film process methods enabling manufacture of high-power density piezoelectric ceramic materials at higher performance and/or reduced cost.  Of importance is that these new materials compositions and innovative materials/electronics engineering processes enable use of low-cost electroding materials such as copper or nickel.

In particular the program focused on multilayer piezoelectric transformers using both the program developed new advanced performance material compositions combined with new piezoelectric thick film process methods. The result is new devices that exhibit higher power density and step-up capability than any previous literature published similar devices. An important part of the program was development of reduced atmosphere, low temperature sintering methods for new hard-type materials meeting requirements for our new copper cofiring process engineering of multilayer structures. This advance opens up new frontiers for high power applications of piezoceramics such as ultrasonic motors, acoustic transducers and transformers.

Important applications that drove the program requirements included both space systems and munitions. Both these arenas similarly require very power dense high gain transformer capabilities that these new devices now offer. An important strategic outcome of this program is that the high-risk research and development of piezoelectric transformer-based charger munitions have now been undertaken as the program developed products had already passed critical test and evaluation steps toward the acquisition.

An important application area for the technology is space systems.  Many plasma physics and small/nano thruster designs have essential requirements for creating high voltage potential fields. There is a complete lack of a good solution to radhard reliable high gain (high voltage) transformers that meet these needs.  The technology developed within this NSF program promises to meet many of these needs.

This program also enabled the successful transition of the developed materials and device technology from university to industry. The program laid the fundamentals and capacitated the expansion of SSC, Inc to be the nation?s only vertically integrated small business capable of producing its own piezoelectric materials, and thick film cofired piezoelectric devices integrated in smart electronic systems. In addition to the program developed transformers, the manufacturing facility started producing and delivering piezoelectric actuators, piezoelectric harvesters and transducer materials to various industries in USA which has been dependent on overseas for piezoelectric products for years.

The thick film processing methods developed under this program for high power density piezoelectric transformers have already spun off the the development of new advanced materials, and technologies. One of these new spin off thick film technologies is textured ceramics, which is identified as the replacement of single crystals by the underwater acoustic transducer industry. Because of the new developed advanced thick film processes and methodologies, SSC have demonstrated such high performance of these new materials that now leading the industry to provide these next next-generation piezoelectric materials domestically for critical product groups to national security such as underwater sonars and sonobuoys.

This NSF STTR program provided several technical and professional training opportunities for undergrad students and postdocs. The program produced two journal papers and one patent.
